Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Productive and Scalable Utilization of Manycores in Big Data Applications

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
Many important electronics applications, including medical imaging, cyber security and digital entertainment, require processing massive amount of data under limited time, power and price budgets. Modern many-core processor chips offer a promising platform for computing such data-intensive workloads, however, their utilization is hindered due to the inherent difficulty and unproductivity of parallel software development at scale.

The project aims to address this critical problem by developing methodologies and tools for productive and scalable development of software that would efficiently run on thousands of processor cores. Central to the approach is development of "functionally-consistent structurally-malleable streaming specification," which enables design-time exploration of a rich software implementation space, under the constraints of hardware platform, while maintaining the application's end-to-end functional behavior. The project results are expected to improve performance, energy consumption, and application development cost in a large number of data-driven disciplines, ranging from medical imaging and cyber security to multimedia and beyond.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project led to development of methodologies, techniques and tools for building efficient data-intensive applications that can take advantage of the many processor cores that exist in modern execution platforms. The project contributed to two set of objectives on the opposing end of the product development spectrum: on one hand, a key focus area was automation and productivity, critical developer facing criteria, which are critical to industry as they impact products time to market and the economics of product development. On the other hand, the project emphasized energy-efficiency and fast execution time, important user experience criteria, which are enabled via concurrent execution of workload on parallel resources in the system. The research findings made positive impact to a number of emerging applications, including image understanding, voice recognition and video analytics, though which, the project contributed to advancements in several important technology disciplines with far reaching societal applications, such as signal processing, multimedia, artificial intelligence and machine learning. In addition to technical contributions to the field, the project broader impacts include community outreach and engagement of a number of local high-school students, and training of a large number of graduate and undergraduate students, including student from under-represented groups, who contributed to the project in various capacities.

 


Last Modified: 05/29/2018
Modified by: Soheil Ghiasi
